description:
Eleusine coracana subsp. coracana, commonly known as finger millet, is a subspecies of the cereal crop plant Eleusine coracana. It is a cultivated species of grass that belongs to the family Poaceae.

Finger millet is an annual, tufted, and erect grass that can grow up to 1.5 meters in height. The plant has linear leaves and distinct finger-like spikes that bear the small, brownish-gray grains. The grains are small, oval-shaped, and have a hard endosperm.

Finger millet is primarily grown for its edible grains, which are used as a staple food in many parts of Africa and Asia. It is known for its nutritional value, as the grains are rich in minerals, such as calcium, iron, and fiber. The crop is also valued for its drought tolerance and resistance to various environmental stresses, making it an important food security crop in many developing regions.

Eleusine coracana subsp. coracana is believed to have originated in the East African region and has been cultivated for thousands of years. It continues to be an important traditional and subsistence crop in many parts of the world.
